Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Northern Embayment Lithosphere Experiment (NELE)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Passage of the EarthScope Transportable Array across the Mississippi Embayment is providing an opportunity to investigate lithospheric structure associated with active deformation and an ancient, intracratonic rift. The Mississippi Embayment is a first-order geological structure of the North American continent with a long and complex geological history affected by at least two periods of continental breakup. The reason for geologically recent basin subsidence is enigmatic since subsidence began about 100 million years ago and is not linked to a major tectonic episode. In addition, the active New Madrid seismic zone (NMSZ) is located in the upper crust within the northern Mississippi Embayment. Lithospheric seismic velocity heterogeneity and anisotropy are likely indicators of the dynamic processes associated with basin subsidence and earthquake genesis in the region.

The seismic experiment incorporates stations of EarthScope's Transportable Array and a higher density FlexArray deployment to provide an overall framework of lithospheric velocity and anisotropy structure to depths exceeding the upper mantle transition zone. Detailed variations in deep structure perpendicular and parallel to the embayment axis are imaged using three dense lines of FlexArray stations that extend within and outside of the Mississippi Embayment. Major issues that are addressed include 1) the primary differences in lithospheric structure between the embayment and the surrounding region, 2) the nature of early Cambrian rifting and relationship to pre-existing structure, 3) the dynamic processes responsible for basin subsidence, and 4) the relationship of the NMSZ to large scale lithospheric structure. This is accomplished through joint interpretation of seismic velocity tomography, potential fields, transfer/receiver functions, and depth-dependent anisotropy images generated using traditional and new geophysical techniques.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Saint Louis University contribution to the Northern Embayment Lithosphere Experiment (ZL temporary network 2011-2015) was to determine surface-wave velocities in the region. Because of interesting features seen, the effort was extended to the entire Central and Eastern U.S. Using over 3.5 million observations of Rayleigh- and Love-wave phase and group velocity dispersion at periods between 2 and 100 seconds from permanent and portable broadband seismograph stations, we were able to make detailed maps on the spatial variation of dispersion. Because of our interest in the shallow part of the Earth's Crust, we used data streams with higher sample rates, which enabled us to get dispersion at periods less than the 4 to 6 seconds usually obtained from 1 sec sampled data streams. Of course this significantly increased the computational effort.

Figure 1 shows the variation of the Rayleigh-wave group velocity at a period of 3.0 secs. Prominent low velocity regions (red) correlate with geological features: Michigan Basin, Mid-continent Rift, Anardarko Basin, Mississippi Embayment and Appalachian foredeep and southern Quebec Basin. We succeeded in imaging shallow structures in the upper crust.

Most dispersion data were obtained by cross-correlating ambient noise  between seismograph station pairs. Surprisingly we found that this technique does not always yield dispersion at short periods.   In many regions short periods are not observed, such as the Gulf Coast where there should be energetic noise sources.  Fig. 2 shows the shortest period that was obtained from the tomography.  To understand the reason for this observation, we created synthetic noise sets for different 1-D  crustal models. The effort showed that deep sediment sites do not provide useful dispersion at short periods. We thus conclude that there are limits to what can be obtained using the modern technique of ambient-noise cross-correlation - sometimes it works and sometimes it does not!

The dispersion study results have several uses beyond this study: for selecting a local  crustal model for the inversion of earhquake fault parameters by waveform modeling, for constraining the local 1-D structure  for earthquake location in regions where a well calibrated local model does not exist, and ultimately as a component for defining the 3-D crust and upper mantle Earth structure with good resolution of the upper, seismogenic crust.  

The results of the tomographic inversions are openly available at 

http://www.eas.slu.edu/eqc/eqc_research/NATOMO/ 

This link provides access to the inversions for the continental US and Canada for a 100 km x 100 km, and for the Central and Eastern US for a 25 km x 25 km grid. For each inversion, the output data files and code to select the dispersion for a given latitude and longitude are provided. In addition GIF animations are provided for the 25 km x 25 km grid inversions; these are used as a quality control measure and as a way to visualize the completeness of the data sets and inversions. The GIF animations progress in order of increasing period, which acts as a surrogate for viewing crustal velocities as a function of depth. The dispersion results have already been used by other researchers.

Computer codes and tutorials on their use are described in the open-source Computer Programs in Seismology package at

http://www.eas.slu.edu/eqc/eqccps.html

Field work involved the 18 month deployment of the stations shown in Figure 3, in cooperation with CERI at the University of Memphis. The continuous data were archived at IRIS (www.iris.edu).
